**Milan Central** or **Milano Centrale** is the main [railway
station](/wiki/Railway_station "Railway station") of the city of
[Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") and one of the main
railway stations in Europe. The station is a terminus and located at the
northern end of central Milan. It was officially inaugurated in 1931 to
replace the old central station (built 1864), which was a transit station but
with a limited number of tracks and space, so could not handle the increased
traffic caused by the opening of the [Simplon tunnel](/wiki/Simplon_Tunnel
"Simplon Tunnel") in 1906.

Milano Centrale has [high speed connections](/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Italy
"High-speed rail in Italy") to [Turin](/wiki/Turin%E2%80%93Milan_high-
speed_railway "Turin–Milan high-speed railway") in the west,
[Venice](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Venice_railway "Milan–Venice railway") via Verona
in the east and on the north-south mainline to
[Bologna](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Bologna_high-speed_railway "Milan–Bologna high-
speed railway"), [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), [Naples](/wiki/Naples "Naples")
and [Salerno](/wiki/Salerno "Salerno"). The Simplon and Gotthard railway lines
connect Milano Centrale to [Bern](/wiki/Bern_railway_station "Bern railway
station") and [Geneva](/wiki/Gen%C3%A8ve-Cornavin_railway_station "Genève-
Cornavin railway station") via
[Domodossola](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Domodossola_railway "Milan–Domodossola
railway") and [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich_Hauptbahnhof "Zürich Hauptbahnhof")
via [Chiasso](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Chiasso_railway "Milan–Chiasso railway") in
Switzerland.

Destinations of inter-city and regional railways radiate from Milano Centrale
to Ventimiglia (border of France), Genova, Turin, Domodossola (border of Swiss
Canton of Valais/Wallis), Tirano (border of Swiss Canton of
Graubünden/Grisons), Bergamo, Verona, Mantova, Bologna and La Spezia.

The [Milan suburban railway service](/wiki/Milan_suburban_railway_service
"Milan suburban railway service"), however, does not use Milano Centrale but
the other mainline stations: Porta Garibaldi (northwest), Cadorna (west) and
Rogoredo (east).

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Milan_Central_railway_station&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The first Milano Centrale station opened in 1864 in the area now occupied by
the _Piazza della Repubblica_ , south of the modern station.[1] It was
designed by French architect [Louis-Jules Bouchot](/wiki/Louis-Jules_Bouchot
"Louis-Jules Bouchot") (1817–1907) and its architectural style was reminiscent
of Parisian buildings of that period. The station was designed to replace
_Porta Tosa station_ (opened in 1846 as the terminus of the line to
[Treviglio](/wiki/Treviglio "Treviglio") and eventually
[Venice](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Venice_railway "Milan–Venice railway")) and
_Porta Nuova station_ (opened in 1850 as the second terminus on the [line to
Monza](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Monza_railway "Milan–Monza railway"), which was
eventually extended to [Chiasso](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Chiasso_railway
"Milan–Chiasso railway")) and was interconnected with all lines, either
existing or under construction, surrounding Milan. It remained in operation
until 30 June 1931, when the current station was opened. There is now no trace
of the old station left.

King [Victor Emmanuel III](/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III "Victor Emmanuel III") of
Italy laid the cornerstone of the new station on April 28, 1906, before a
blueprint for the station had even been chosen. The last, real, contest for
its construction was won in 1912 by [architect](/wiki/Architect "Architect")
[Ulisse Stacchini](/wiki/Ulisse_Stacchini "Ulisse Stacchini"), whose design
was modeled after [Union Station](/wiki/Union_Station_\(Washington,_D.C.\)
"Union Station \(Washington, D.C.\)") in [Washington, DC](/wiki/Washington,_DC
"Washington, DC"),[2] and the construction of the new station began. The
purported style was an eclectic mix called "Assyrian-Lombard."[3]

Due to the Italian economic crisis during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I
"World War I"), construction proceeded very slowly, and the project, rather
simple at the beginning, kept changing and became more and more complex and
majestic. This happened especially when [Benito
Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") became [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy "Prime Minister of Italy"), and wanted
the station to represent the power of the [Fascist](/wiki/Italian_Fascism
"Italian Fascism") regime.[4] The major changes were the new
[platform](/wiki/Railway_platform "Railway platform") types and the
introduction of the great steel [canopies](/wiki/Canopy_\(building\) "Canopy
\(building\)") by Alberto Fava; 341 m (1,119 ft) long and covering an area of
66,500 square metres (716,000 sq ft).

Construction resumed in earnest in 1925 and on July 1, 1931, the station was
officially opened in the presence of Foreign Minister [Galeazzo
Ciano](/wiki/Galeazzo_Ciano "Galeazzo Ciano").

Its façade is 200 metres (660 ft) wide and its vault is 72 metres (236 ft)
high, a record when it was built. It has 24 platforms. Each day about 330,000
passengers use the station, totaling about 120 million per year.

The station has no definite architectural style, but is a blend of many
different styles, especially [Liberty](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") and
[Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"), but not limited to those. It is adorned
with numerous sculptures. “The ‘incongruous envelope of stone’ (Attilio
Pracchi) of this gigantic and monumental building dominates Piazza Duca
d’Aosta.” [5]

On September 25, 2006, officials announced a [€](/wiki/Euro "Euro")100 million
project, already in progress, to refurbish the station. Of the total cost, €20
million has been allocated to restore "certain areas of high artistic value"
while the remaining €80 million will be used for more general improvements to
the station to make it more functional with the current railway services. The
project includes moving the ticket office and installing new elevators and
escalators for increased accessibility.[6]

There remains unrestored and inaccessible areas to the public within the
station including a waiting room with [swastikas](/wiki/Swastika "Swastika")
on the floor designed to receive Hitler.[3]

## Train
services[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Milan_Central_railway_station&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Train services")]

The station has 24 tracks. Every day about 320,000 passengers pass through the
station using about 500 trains, for an annual total of 120 million passengers.
The station is served by national and international routes, with both long-
distance and regional lines. Daily international destinations include
[Bern](/wiki/Bern "Bern"), [Lugano](/wiki/Lugano "Lugano"),
[Geneva](/wiki/Geneva "Geneva"), [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"),
[Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"),
[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") and [Munich](/wiki/Munich
"Munich").[7] The station is also connected to [Milan-Malpensa
Airport](/wiki/Milan-Malpensa_Airport "Milan-Malpensa Airport") through the
[Malpensa Express](/wiki/Malpensa_Express "Malpensa Express") airport train.

The following services call at the station (incomplete):

services. There is no train service of [Milan
Suburbano](/wiki/Milan_suburban_railway_service "Milan suburban railway
service") at the Centrale station.

  * Night train ([Trenitalia](/wiki/Trenitalia "Trenitalia") Intercity Notte) **Milan-Lecce** : Milan - Piacenza - Parma - Reggio d'Emilia - Modena - Bologna - Cesana - Rimini - Ancona - Pescara - Foggia - Bari - Trani - Brindisi - Lecce

### Cross-border (Night
train)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Milan_Central_railway_station&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Cross-border \(Night train\)")]

(CH for Switzerland, D for Germany, A for Austria, F for France, MN for
Monaco)

On 11 December 2016, ÖBB will take over Deutsche Bahn's night trains. The
Munich-Milan service will be withdrawn.

  * Night train ([Thello](/wiki/Thello "Thello") EuroNight) **Paris-Venice** : Venice - Padua - Verona - Milan (Centrale) - Milan (Rho-Fiera for Expo 2015) - Dijon (F) - Paris (F)
  * Night train ([DB](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") [City Night Line](/wiki/City_Night_Line "City Night Line")) **Milan-Munich/Vienna** : Milan - Brescia - Peschiera del Garda - Verona^ - (Rovereto/Rofreit) - (Trento/Trient) - Bolzano/Bozen - (Brennero/Brenner) - Innsbruck (A) - Jenbach (A) - Kufstein (A) - Munich (D)

^ Train connects at Verona with ÖBB EuroNight Rome-Vienna: DB CityNightLine
splits into two trains (first half couples with ÖBB Rome-Vienna and leaves for
Vienna or Rome; second half continues to Munich or Milan). Vienna-Rome splits
into two trains (first half continues to Rome or Vienna; second half couples
with DB CityNightLine for Milan or Munich).

### Cross-
border[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Milan_Central_railway_station&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Cross-border")]

After the opening of [Gotthard Base Tunnel](/wiki/Gotthard_Base_Tunnel
"Gotthard Base Tunnel"), train services between Milan and Switzerland will
increase in frequency from 11 December 2016. All [SBB-CFF-
FSS](/wiki/Swiss_Federal_Railways "Swiss Federal Railways") Eurocity will save
35 minutes of total journey time between Bellinzona and Arth-Goldau.

From December 2017, a new cross-border service **Milan-Frankfurt** (DB-SBB
Eurocity) via Zürich will be operational.

  * Regional train ([TiLo](/wiki/Treni_Regionali_Ticino_Lombardia "Treni Regionali Ticino Lombardia") Regio) **Milan-Bellinzona** : Milan - Monza - Como (San Giovanni) - Chiasso (CH) - Lugano (CH) - Bellinzona (CH)
  * Intercity train ([SBB-CFF-FSS](/wiki/Swiss_Federal_Railways "Swiss Federal Railways") EuroCity) **Geneva-Milan/Venice** : Geneva/Genf (CH) - Lausanne (CH) - Brig (CH) - Domodossola - Milan - (Brescia) - (Verona) - (Padua) - (Venice)
  * Intercity train ([SBB-CFF-FSS](/wiki/Swiss_Federal_Railways "Swiss Federal Railways") EuroCity) **Basel-Milan** : Basel SBB (CH) - Bern/Berne (CH) - Thun (CH) - Brig (CH) - Domodossola - Stresa - Busto Arsizio - Milan
  * Intercity train ([SBB-CFF-FSS](/wiki/Swiss_Federal_Railways "Swiss Federal Railways") EuroCity) **Zürich-Milan** : Zürich (CH) - Zug (CH) - Arth-Goldau (CH) - Bellinzona (CH) - Lugano (CH) - Chiasso (CH) - Como (San Giovanni) - Monza - Milan
  * Intercity train ([SBB-CFF-FSS](/wiki/Swiss_Federal_Railways "Swiss Federal Railways") EuroCity) **Luzern-Milan** : Luzern (CH) - Arth-Goldau (CH) - Bellinzona (CH) - Lugano (CH) - Chiasso (CH) - Como (San Giovanni) - Monza - Milan
  * Intercity train ([Thello](/wiki/Thello "Thello") EuroCity) **Milan-Marseilles** : Milan - Genoa - San Remo - Menton (F) - Monaco Monte Carlo (MN) - Nice (F) - Cannes (F) - Marseille (F)

The station, along with [Roma Termini](/wiki/Roma_Termini_railway_station
"Roma Termini railway station") and [Firenze Santa Maria
Novella](/wiki/Firenze_Santa_Maria_Novella_railway_station "Firenze Santa
Maria Novella railway station"), has **security gates** which prevent access
to the platforms without a ticket.

Each platform is usually dedicated to some particular route. The current
organization is as follows, although temporary changes may occur.

  * Platforms 1-3: [Chiasso](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Chiasso_railway "Milan–Chiasso railway")/[Domodossola](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Domodossola_railway "Milan–Domodossola railway")/[Milan-Turin (ES* AV)](/wiki/Turin%E2%80%93Milan_high-speed_railway "Turin–Milan high-speed railway")
  * Platforms 4-6: [Turin](/wiki/Turin%E2%80%93Milan_railway "Turin–Milan railway")/[Cisalpino](/wiki/Cisalpino "Cisalpino") Milan–[Como](/wiki/Como "Como")–[Arth Goldau](/wiki/Arth "Arth")–[Basel](/wiki/Basel_SBB_railway_station "Basel SBB railway station") / [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich_Hauptbahnhof "Zürich Hauptbahnhof")
  * Platforms 7-13: [Venice](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Venice_railway "Milan–Venice railway") / [Udine](/wiki/Udine "Udine")
  * Platforms 14-17: [Bologna](/wiki/Milan%E2%80%93Bologna_high-speed_railway "Milan–Bologna high-speed railway")–[Florence](/wiki/Firenze_Santa_Maria_Novella_railway_station "Firenze Santa Maria Novella railway station")–[Rome](/wiki/Roma_Termini_railway_station "Roma Termini railway station")–[Naples](/wiki/Napoli_Centrale_railway_station "Napoli Centrale railway station")
  * Platforms 18-23: [Genoa](/wiki/Genoa%E2%80%93Milan_railway "Genoa–Milan railway")-[Livorno](/wiki/Pisa%E2%80%93La_Spezia%E2%80%93Genoa_railway "Pisa–La Spezia–Genoa railway") / [Ventimiglia](/wiki/Genoa%E2%80%93Ventimiglia_railway "Genoa–Ventimiglia railway") / [Parma](/wiki/Parma "Parma") /[Cremona](/wiki/Cremona "Cremona")-[Mantua](/wiki/Mantua "Mantua") /Milan-[Treviglio](/wiki/Treviglio "Treviglio")-[Bergamo](/wiki/Bergamo "Bergamo")
  * Platform 24: Operations

### Unusual track
layout[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Milan_Central_railway_station&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Unusual track layout")]

On the northern side of the railway yard there used to be a loop curve so that
trains could turn around and reverse back into the station. The trains could
so be displaced from the left side of the station to the right side and vice
versa without crossing all the tracks. The tracks on the loop curve are
partially broken up.[8]
